title: Federal Reserve
text:
Bill Dudley, former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, opines about the Fed's reactions to the trade war.

"So, according to conventional wisdom, if Trump’s trade war with China hurts the U.S. economic outlook,

the Fed should respond by adjusting monetary policy accordingly — in this case by cutting interest rates.

But what if the Fed’s accommodation encourages the president to escalate the trade war further,

increasing the risk of a recession? The central bank’s efforts to cushion the blow might not be merely

ineffectual. They might actually make things worse."
